Headline: I help purpose-driven teams mint monies!
Comment:
Absolutely agree. In India, distribution moats often outlast product moats because they‚Äôre rooted in trust, cultural context, and ground-level muscle.

Two things I‚Äôve seen stand out:

1. Embedded rails ‚Äì piggybacking on existing payment, retail, or mobility networks gives startups distribution at near-zero CAC.

2. Behavioral loops ‚Äì distribution that ties into daily/weekly rituals (chai, kirana visits, salary day) compounds far faster than ad spends.

The real edge isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwho can build the best app,‚Äù but ‚Äúwho can embed themselves most seamlessly into the consumer‚Äôs everyday.‚Äù 

That‚Äôs the moat that keeps widening.
processed_comment: absolutely agree in india distribution moats often outlast product moats because theyre rooted in trust cultural context and groundlevel muscle two things ive seen stand out embedded rails piggybacking on existing payment retail or mobility networks gives startups distribution at nearzero cac behavioral loops distribution that ties into dailyweekly rituals chai kirana visits salary day compounds far faster than ad spends the real edge isnt who can build the best app but who can embed themselves most seamlessly into the consumers everyday thats the moat that keeps widening

Headline: Hospital Transformation | CRM & MSME Automation Expert | 30+ Years Driving Growth with Tech, Process & Empathy | Hospitune ‚Ä¢ Abhiyaan ‚Ä¢ Be(VP)roductive
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala

In my experience, products rarely fail because they lacked innovation. They struggle because they never built a sustainable way to reach and retain customers.

Distribution is where trust, consistency, and culture come together. In India, this could mean something as simple as a shopkeeper in a small town recommending your brand, or as deep as creating rituals that make your product part of everyday life.

The real moat is not just access, but the relationship you build over time. That is what keeps competitors at bay.

Headline: 15 years in senior leadership, 40 years total experience, frontline sales, channel growth, profit center management , man management, training and mentoring, digital enabler.
Comment:
After evolution of online business model like Amazon, Flipkart and QS like Zepto, Blinkit etc, the whole FMCG distribution dynamics has changed. Yes once it was a MOAT for new entrants to match the deep rooted distribution, because their volumes were low and cost of distribution was high. With last mile delivery made available with double digit growth in small commercial vehicles, a hub and spoke model has emerged where better efficiency   at low cost/unit. 
Of course the QS companies have not yet reached to tier 2/3 towns, but sooner or later they will, and then it will no more a moat.
processed_comment: after evolution of online business model like amazon flipkart and qs like zepto blinkit etc the whole fmcg distribution dynamics has changed yes once it was a moat for new entrants to match the deep rooted distribution because their volumes were low and cost of distribution was high with last mile delivery made available with double digit growth in small commercial vehicles a hub and spoke model has emerged where better efficiency at low costunit of course the qs companies have not yet reached to tier towns but sooner or later they will and then it will no more a moat
